title: 外媒評 英超十大最佳 亞洲足協球員 ，孫繼海不入流

replies.msg:
The past week was a good one for Asian players in the Premier League, with South Korean Son Heung-Min and Australian Aaron Mooy netting for their respective clubs. FFT picks the top ten players from the region who have graced English football's greatest stage...

Shinji Kagawa 香川真司 (日本)
Shinji Kagawa arrived at Old Trafford on the back of a very successful 2011-2012 Bundesliga season, where he helped Borussia Dortmund to the Bundesliga title.
While he did not replicate his impressive form on the same level for Manchester United, Kagawa still managed to become the first Japanese player to lift the Premier League trophy as well as being the first Asian player to score a hat-trick in the league.


Kagawa was unlucky with injuries as well, and while his stint at the club only lasted two seasons - most fans would agree that he gave a good account of himself.
He is currently back in Germany with Dortmund, where he has established himself as one of the fan favourites with the German giants and last month became the leading Japanese scorer in Bundesliga history with 38 goals.

Ali Al-Habsi 艾哈比斯 (阿曼)
The imposing Omani stopper spent most of this playing career in England, featuring for Bolton and Wigan Athletic.
Al-Habsimade his name with the Latics in the Premier League - not just as an outstanding penalty stopper but a goalkeeper with excellent reflexes.



Maya Yoshida 吉田麻也 (日本)
Yoshida is the only defender to make this list, emphasizing his contribution to the Premier League thus far.
While he endured a shaky start to life in England, Yoshida has become a reliable asset at the back for Southampton, racking up over 100 appearances for the Saints over the past five seasons.
image: ?itok=yfMrKSXw

His versatility across the backline has proven a plus for the club and he even takes a decent set-piece.
Given their defensive woes, don't be surprised if Liverpool start showing interest in signing him!

Ki Sung-Yeung奇誠庸 (韓國)
Captain of the South Korea national team, Ki was signed by the Swansea in 2012 for six million pounds after he caught the eye at Celtic.
A technically gifted footballer, Ki is an underrated midfielder, who possesses the ability to pick out a long-range pass.
image: ?itok=HuD45vNd

His contributions to the club have not gone unnoticed, as he was voted Swansea City Player of the Year in the 2014-2015 season.
Having recently recovered from a knee injury, the 28-year-old will hope to be the “Ki” to turn the fortunes for the Swans this season.

Harry Kewell 基維爾 (澳洲)
The winger with a wand of a left foot was unplayable at his prime and if not for his perpetual injuries, Kewell could have enjoyed even more success in the Premier League.
After making a name for himself at Leeds United, he moved to his boyhood club Liverpool and donned the legendary number seven jersey.
image: ?itok=3Gn2ubc-

Kewell was so valued by the Reds that former manager Gerard Houllier revealed last month that Liverpool decided against signing Cristiano Ronaldo due of CR7's wage demands and also because they already had Kewell.
A more than questionable decision on hindsight perhaps, but with a Champions League medal and more than 250 appearances under his belt in the Premier League, it is safe to say that Kewell has established himself as one of Australian football’s legends.
[NEXT: Three Lungs Park and Son-sational Heung-Min]

Park Ji Sung 朴智星 (韓國)
​Undoubtedly the most successful Asian in the Premier League, Park Ji Sung has won almost every major honour in English club football.
The Red Devils had one of the most hardworking players at their disposal in Park, not to mention his knack of scoring important goals for them as well.
Park's immense contribution to Manchester United during his 7-year career will be remembered
"Three-Lungs Park" as he is affectionately known, was the first Asian to captain Manchester United and also the first to win the Champions League.
Currently a global ambassador for the Red Devils, his appointment is a testament to the immense contribution to the club during his 7-year career at Old Trafford.


Tim Cahill 卡希爾 (澳洲)
Fondly remembered for his boxing antics with several unfortunate corner flags, the former Everton forward goes down as one of the most memorable Australians to ever graced the Premier League.
A hero for both club and country, Cahill's performances even gave him a place on the 50 player nominee list for the Ballon D’Or list in 2006.
image: ?itok=bh-FiQxN

A diminutive player, Cahill's aerial abilities are almost legendary, having scored a great number of heading goals.
Nearing the tail-end of this career playing for Melbourne City in the A-League, Cahill continues to star for Australia, recently scoring a brace against Syria to keep the Socceroos' World Cup hopes alive.
No guesses as to how he scored...

Son Heung-Min 孫興慜 (韓國)
​A relative newcomer to the Premier League, Son Heung-Min did not exactly set the world alight after his arrival from the Bundesliga in 2015.
Given the lack of playing time, Son was on the verge of a move away from Tottenham Hotspur but opted to fight for his place instead.

His decision proved to be a hugely successful one, with Son totally transformed into a invaluable member of the first team squad.
Given the current form he is in, we will be sure to see many more of his elaborate handshakes with his Spurs teammates.

Shinji Okazaki 岡崎慎司 (日本)
Part of the Leicester City squad who shocked the world of sport by claiming the Premier League title two season ago, Okazaki's workrate is second to none.
While he is not a striker known for his goalscoring exploits, Okazaki makes up for it with his hard work and consistency, and remains an integral member of the Premier League side.
image: ?itok=4Mv4Xj26

He already has three goals in all appearances this season and will want to impress incoming manager Claude Puel as the Foxes look to climb the table.

Mark Schwarzer 舒華沙 (澳洲)
If there was ever a word to describe Mark Schwarzer, it would be "longevity".
One of the Premier League longest serving goalkeepers, the 45-year-old played for four Premier League teams, spending almost 20 years in English football.
He has also set several Premier League records along the way.
image: ?itok=Y81hMSDp

Schwarzer was the first player to have won back-to-back Premier League trophies with two different clubs - Chelsea and Leicester, although he only made a few appearances in his role as back-up.
He is also the oldest Premier League title winner at the tender age of 43-years-old.
